desc: Configuration for EMQX dashboard.

fields.desc:
HTTP(s) listeners are identified by their protocol type and are
used to serve dashboard UI and restful HTTP API.
Listeners must have a unique combination of port number and IP address.
For example, an HTTP listener can listen on all configured IP addresses
on a given port for a machine by specifying the IP address 0.0.0.0.
Alternatively, the HTTP listener can specify a unique IP address for each listener,
but use the same port.
fields.name: listeners

fields.desc: The default username of the automatically created dashboard user.
fields.name: default_username

fields.desc:
The initial default password for dashboard 'admin' user.
For safety, it should be changed as soon as possible.
fields.name: default_password

fields.desc:
How often to update metrics displayed in the dashboard.
Note: `sample_interval` should be a divisor of 60.
fields.name: sample_interval

fields.desc: JWT token expiration time.
fields.name: token_expired_time

fields.desc:
Support Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS).
Allows a server to indicate any origins (domain, scheme, or port) other than
its own from which a browser should permit loading resources.
fields.name: cors

fields.desc: Internationalization language support.
fields.name: i18n_lang

fields.desc: Initialize users file.
fields.name: bootstrap_users_file

desc: Configuration for the dashboard listener (plaintext).

fields.desc: Ignore or enable this listener
fields.name: enable

fields.desc: Port without IP(18083) or port with specified IP(127.0.0.1:18083).
fields.name: bind

fields.desc: Socket acceptor pool size for TCP protocols.
fields.name: num_acceptors

fields.desc: Maximum number of simultaneous connections.
fields.name: max_connections

fields.desc: Defines the maximum length that the queue of pending connections can grow to.
fields.name: backlog

fields.desc: Send timeout for the socket.
fields.name: send_timeout

fields.desc: Enable IPv6 support, default is false, which means IPv4 only.
fields.name: inet6

fields.desc: Disable IPv4-to-IPv6 mapping for the listener.
fields.name: ipv6_v6only

desc: Configuration for the dashboard listener (TLS).

fields.desc: Ignore or enable this listener
fields.name: enable

fields.desc: Port without IP(18083) or port with specified IP(127.0.0.1:18083).
fields.name: bind

fields.desc: Socket acceptor pool size for TCP protocols.
fields.name: num_acceptors

fields.desc: Maximum number of simultaneous connections.
fields.name: max_connections

fields.desc: Defines the maximum length that the queue of pending connections can grow to.
fields.name: backlog

fields.desc: Send timeout for the socket.
fields.name: send_timeout

fields.desc: Enable IPv6 support, default is false, which means IPv4 only.
fields.name: inet6

fields.desc: Disable IPv4-to-IPv6 mapping for the listener.
fields.name: ipv6_v6only

fields.desc:
Trusted PEM format CA certificates bundle file.
The certificates in this file are used to verify the TLS peer's certificates. Append new certificates to the file if new CAs are to be trusted. There is no need to restart EMQX to have the updated file loaded, because the system regularly checks if file has been updated (and reload).
NOTE: invalidating (deleting) a certificate from the file will not affect already established connections.
fields.name: cacertfile

fields.desc:
PEM format certificates chain file.
The certificates in this file should be in reversed order of the certificate issue chain. That is, the host's certificate should be placed in the beginning of the file, followed by the immediate issuer certificate and so on. Although the root CA certificate is optional, it should be placed at the end of the file if it is to be added.
fields.name: certfile

fields.desc: PEM format private key file.
fields.name: keyfile

fields.desc: Enable or disable peer verification.
fields.name: verify

fields.desc: Enable TLS session reuse.
fields.name: reuse_sessions

fields.desc:
Maximum number of non-self-issued intermediate certificates that can follow the peer certificate in a valid certification path. So, if depth is 0 the PEER must be signed by the trusted ROOT-CA directly;
if 1 the path can be PEER, Intermediate-CA, ROOT-CA;
if 2 the path can be PEER, Intermediate-CA1, Intermediate-CA2, ROOT-CA.
fields.name: depth

fields.desc:
String containing the user's password.
Only used if the private key file is password-protected.
fields.name: password

fields.desc:
All TLS/DTLS versions to be supported.
NOTE: PSK ciphers are suppressed by 'tlsv1.3' version config.
In case PSK cipher suites are intended, make sure to configure ['tlsv1.2', 'tlsv1.1'] here.
fields.name: versions

fields.desc:
This config holds TLS cipher suite names separated by comma, or as an array of strings. e.g. "TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256" or ["TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384","TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256"].
Ciphers (and their ordering) define the way in which the client and server encrypts information over the network connection. Selecting a good cipher suite is critical for the application's data security, confidentiality and performance. The names should be in OpenSSL string format (not RFC format). All default values and examples provided by EMQX config documentation are all in OpenSSL format.
NOTE: Certain cipher suites are only compatible with specific TLS versions ('tlsv1.1', 'tlsv1.2' or 'tlsv1.3') incompatible cipher suites will be silently dropped. For instance, if only 'tlsv1.3' is given in the versions, configuring cipher suites for other versions will have no effect.
NOTE: PSK ciphers are suppressed by 'tlsv1.3' version config
If PSK cipher suites are intended, 'tlsv1.3' should be disabled from versions.
PSK cipher suites: "RSA-PSK-AES256-GCM-SHA384,RSA-PSK-AES256-CBC-SHA384, RSA-PSK-AES128-GCM-SHA256,RSA-PSK-AES128-CBC-SHA256, RSA-PSK-AES256-CBC-SHA,RSA-PSK-AES128-CBC-SHA, RSA-PSK-DES-CBC3-SHA,RSA-PSK-RC4-SHA"
fields.name: ciphers

fields.desc: EMQX-internal callback that is used to lookup pre-shared key (PSK) identity.
fields.name: user_lookup_fun

fields.desc:
SSL parameter renegotiation is a feature that allows a client and a server
to renegotiate the parameters of the SSL connection on the fly.
RFC 5746 defines a more secure way of doing this. By enabling secure renegotiation,
you drop support for the insecure renegotiation, prone to MitM attacks.
fields.name: secure_renegotiate

fields.desc:
Path to a file containing PEM-encoded Diffie-Hellman parameters to be used by the server if a cipher suite using Diffie-Hellman key exchange is negotiated. If not specified, default parameters are used.
NOTE: The dhfile option is not supported by TLS 1.3.
fields.name: dhfile

fields.desc:
An important security setting, it forces the cipher to be set based
 on the server-specified order instead of the client-specified order,
 hence enforcing the (usually more properly configured) security
 ordering of the server administrator.
fields.name: honor_cipher_order

fields.desc:
In protocols that support client-initiated renegotiation,
the cost of resources of such an operation is higher for the server than the client.
This can act as a vector for denial of service attacks.
The SSL application already takes measures to counter-act such attempts,
but client-initiated renegotiation can be strictly disabled by setting this option to false.
The default value is true. Note that disabling renegotiation can result in
long-lived connections becoming unusable due to limits on
the number of messages the underlying cipher suite can encipher.
fields.name: client_renegotiation

fields.desc: Maximum time duration allowed for the handshake to complete
fields.name: handshake_timeout

desc: Configuration for the dashboard listener.

fields.desc: TCP listeners
fields.name: http

fields.desc: SSL listeners
fields.name: https

desc: External hook (exhook) configuration.

fields.desc: List of exhook servers
fields.name: servers

desc: gRPC server configuration.

fields.desc: Name of the exhook server
fields.name: name

fields.desc: Enable this Exhook server
fields.name: enable

fields.desc: URL of the gRPC server
fields.name: url

fields.desc: The timeout of request gRPC server
fields.name: request_timeout

fields.desc: The value that is returned when the request to the gRPC server fails for any reason
fields.name: failed_action

fields.desc:
Whether to automatically reconnect (initialize) the gRPC server.
When gRPC is not available, Exhook tries to request the gRPC service at that interval and reinitialize the list of mounted hooks.
fields.name: auto_reconnect

fields.desc: The process pool size for gRPC client
fields.name: pool_size

desc: Connection socket options

fields.desc:
Enables/disables periodic transmission on a connected socket when no other data is exchanged.
If the other end does not respond, the connection is considered broken and an error message is sent to the controlling process.
fields.name: keepalive

fields.desc:
If true, option TCP_NODELAY is turned on for the socket,
which means that also small amounts of data are sent immediately
fields.name: nodelay

fields.desc: The minimum size of receive buffer to use for the socket
fields.name: recbuf

fields.desc: The minimum size of send buffer to use for the socket
fields.name: sndbuf

desc: SSL client configuration.

fields.desc:
Trusted PEM format CA certificates bundle file.
The certificates in this file are used to verify the TLS peer's certificates. Append new certificates to the file if new CAs are to be trusted. There is no need to restart EMQX to have the updated file loaded, because the system regularly checks if file has been updated (and reload).
NOTE: invalidating (deleting) a certificate from the file will not affect already established connections.
fields.name: cacertfile

fields.desc:
PEM format certificates chain file.
The certificates in this file should be in reversed order of the certificate issue chain. That is, the host's certificate should be placed in the beginning of the file, followed by the immediate issuer certificate and so on. Although the root CA certificate is optional, it should be placed at the end of the file if it is to be added.
fields.name: certfile

fields.desc: PEM format private key file.
fields.name: keyfile

fields.desc: Enable or disable peer verification.
fields.name: verify

fields.desc: Enable TLS session reuse.
fields.name: reuse_sessions

fields.desc:
Maximum number of non-self-issued intermediate certificates that can follow the peer certificate in a valid certification path. So, if depth is 0 the PEER must be signed by the trusted ROOT-CA directly;
if 1 the path can be PEER, Intermediate-CA, ROOT-CA;
if 2 the path can be PEER, Intermediate-CA1, Intermediate-CA2, ROOT-CA.
fields.name: depth

fields.desc:
String containing the user's password.
Only used if the private key file is password-protected.
fields.name: password

fields.desc:
All TLS/DTLS versions to be supported.
NOTE: PSK ciphers are suppressed by 'tlsv1.3' version config.
In case PSK cipher suites are intended, make sure to configure ['tlsv1.2', 'tlsv1.1'] here.
fields.name: versions

fields.desc:
This config holds TLS cipher suite names separated by comma, or as an array of strings. e.g. "TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256" or ["TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384","TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256"].
Ciphers (and their ordering) define the way in which the client and server encrypts information over the network connection. Selecting a good cipher suite is critical for the application's data security, confidentiality and performance. The names should be in OpenSSL string format (not RFC format). All default values and examples provided by EMQX config documentation are all in OpenSSL format.
NOTE: Certain cipher suites are only compatible with specific TLS versions ('tlsv1.1', 'tlsv1.2' or 'tlsv1.3') incompatible cipher suites will be silently dropped. For instance, if only 'tlsv1.3' is given in the versions, configuring cipher suites for other versions will have no effect.
NOTE: PSK ciphers are suppressed by 'tlsv1.3' version config
If PSK cipher suites are intended, 'tlsv1.3' should be disabled from versions.
PSK cipher suites: "RSA-PSK-AES256-GCM-SHA384,RSA-PSK-AES256-CBC-SHA384, RSA-PSK-AES128-GCM-SHA256,RSA-PSK-AES128-CBC-SHA256, RSA-PSK-AES256-CBC-SHA,RSA-PSK-AES128-CBC-SHA, RSA-PSK-DES-CBC3-SHA,RSA-PSK-RC4-SHA"
fields.name: ciphers

fields.desc:
SSL parameter renegotiation is a feature that allows a client and a server
to renegotiate the parameters of the SSL connection on the fly.
RFC 5746 defines a more secure way of doing this. By enabling secure renegotiation,
you drop support for the insecure renegotiation, prone to MitM attacks.
fields.name: secure_renegotiate

fields.desc: Enable TLS.
fields.name: enable

fields.desc:
Specify the host name to be used in TLS Server Name Indication extension.
For instance, when connecting to "server.example.net", the genuine server which accepts the connection and performs TLS handshake may differ from the host the TLS client initially connects to, e.g. when connecting to an IP address or when the host has multiple resolvable DNS records
If not specified, it will default to the host name string which is used to establish the connection, unless it is IP addressed used.
The host name is then also used in the host name verification of the peer certificate.
The special value 'disable' prevents the Server Name Indication extension from being sent and disables the hostname verification check.
fields.name: server_name_indication

The burst, This value is based on rate.

desc: Settings for the delayed module.

fields.desc: Enable this feature
fields.name: enable

fields.desc: Maximum number of delayed messages (0 is no limit).
fields.name: max_delayed_messages

desc:
The topic rewriting function of EMQX supports rewriting topic A to topic B when the client subscribes to topics, publishes messages, and cancels subscriptions according to user-configured rules.
Each rewrite rule consists of three parts: subject filter, regular expression, and target expression.
Under the premise that the subject rewriting function is enabled, when EMQX receives a subject-based MQTT message such as a `PUBLISH` message,
it will use the subject of the message to sequentially match the subject filter part of the rule in the configuration file. If the match is successful,
the regular expression is used to extract the information in the subject, and then replaced with the target expression to form a new subject.
Variables in the format of `$N` can be used in the target expression to match the elements extracted from the regular expression.
The value of `$N` is the Nth element extracted from the regular expression. For example, `$1` is the regular expression. The first element extracted by the expression.
It should be noted that EMQX uses reverse order to read the rewrite rules in the configuration file.
When a topic can match the topic filter of multiple topic rewrite rules at the same time, EMQX will only use the first rule it matches. Rewrite.
If the regular expression in this rule does not match the subject of the MQTT message, the rewriting will fail, and no other rules will be attempted for rewriting.
Therefore, users need to carefully design MQTT message topics and topic rewriting rules when using them.

fields.desc:
Topic rewriting takes effect on the type of operation:
  - `subscribe`: Rewrite topic when client do subscribe.
  - `publish`: Rewrite topic when client do publish.
  - `all`: Both
fields.name: action

fields.desc: Source topic, specified by the client.
fields.name: source_topic

fields.desc: Destination topic.
fields.name: dest_topic

fields.desc: Regular expressions
fields.name: re

fields.desc: Enable telemetry.
fields.name: enable

fields.desc: Collect metrics for the topic.
fields.name: topic

fields.desc: Max Overflow.
fields.name: max_overflow

fields.desc: Time interval, such as timeout or TTL.
fields.name: overflow_ttl

fields.desc: Time interval, such as timeout or TTL.
fields.name: overflow_check_period

fields.desc: Time interval, such as timeout or TTL.
fields.name: local_threshold_ms

fields.desc: Time interval, such as timeout or TTL.
fields.name: connect_timeout_ms

fields.desc: Time interval, such as timeout or TTL.
fields.name: socket_timeout_ms

fields.desc: Time interval, such as timeout or TTL.
fields.name: server_selection_timeout_ms

fields.desc: Time interval, such as timeout or TTL.
fields.name: wait_queue_timeout_ms

fields.desc: Time interval, such as timeout or TTL.
fields.name: heartbeat_frequency_ms

fields.desc: Time interval, such as timeout or TTL.
fields.name: min_heartbeat_frequency_ms

desc:
Settings for `conn_congestion` alarm.

Sometimes the MQTT connection (usually an MQTT subscriber) may
get "congested", because there are too many packets to be sent.
The socket tries to buffer the packets until the buffer is
full. If more packets arrive after that, the packets will be
"pending" in the queue, and we consider the connection
congested.

Note: `sndbuf` can be set to larger value if the
alarm is triggered too often.
The name of the alarm is of format `conn_congestion/<ClientID>/<Username>`,
where the `<ClientID>` is the client ID of the congested MQTT connection,
and `<Username>` is the username or `unknown_user`.

fields.desc: Enable or disable connection congestion alarm.
fields.name: enable_alarm

fields.desc:
Minimal time before clearing the alarm.
The alarm is cleared only when there's no pending data in
the queue, and at least min_alarm_sustain_durationmilliseconds passed since the last time we considered the connection 'congested'.
This is to avoid clearing and raising the alarm again too often.
fields.name: min_alarm_sustain_duration

desc:
This config controls the allowed maximum number of `CONNECT` packets received
from the same clientid in a time frame defined by `window_time`.
After the limit is reached, successive `CONNECT` requests are forbidden
(banned) until the end of the time period defined by `ban_time`.

fields.desc: Enable flapping connection detection feature.
fields.name: enable

fields.desc: The maximum number of disconnects allowed for a MQTT Client in `window_time`
fields.name: max_count

fields.desc: The time window for flapping detection.
fields.name: window_time

fields.desc: How long the flapping clientid will be banned.
fields.name: ban_time

desc:
Force garbage collection in MQTT connection process after
 they process certain number of messages or bytes of data.

fields.desc: Enable forced garbage collection.
fields.name: enable

fields.desc: GC the process after this many received messages.
fields.name: count

fields.desc: GC the process after specified number of bytes have passed through.
fields.name: bytes

desc:
When the process message queue length, or the memory bytes
reaches a certain value, the process is forced to close.

Note: "message queue" here refers to the "message mailbox"
of the Erlang process, not the `mqueue` of QoS 1 and QoS 2.

fields.desc: Enable `force_shutdown` feature.
fields.name: enable

fields.desc: Maximum message queue length.
fields.name: max_message_queue_len

fields.desc: Total heap size
fields.name: max_heap_size

desc:
Global MQTT configuration.
The configs here work as default values which can be overridden in zone configs

fields.desc: After the TCP connection is established, if the MQTT CONNECT packet from the client is not received within the time specified by idle_timeout, the connection will be disconnected.
fields.name: idle_timeout

fields.desc: Maximum MQTT packet size allowed.
fields.name: max_packet_size

fields.desc: Maximum allowed length of MQTT Client ID.
fields.name: max_clientid_len

fields.desc: Maximum topic levels allowed.
fields.name: max_topic_levels

fields.desc: Maximum QoS allowed.
fields.name: max_qos_allowed

fields.desc: Maximum topic alias, 0 means no topic alias supported.
fields.name: max_topic_alias

fields.desc: Whether to enable support for MQTT retained message.
fields.name: retain_available

fields.desc: Whether to enable support for MQTT wildcard subscription.
fields.name: wildcard_subscription

fields.desc: Whether to enable support for MQTT shared subscription.
fields.name: shared_subscription

fields.desc: Whether to enable support for MQTT exclusive subscription.
fields.name: exclusive_subscription

fields.desc: Ignore loop delivery of messages for MQTT v3.1.1/v3.1.0, similar to No Local subscription option in MQTT 5.0.
fields.name: ignore_loop_deliver

fields.desc:
Parse MQTT messages in strict mode.
When set to true, invalid utf8 strings in for example client ID, topic name, etc. will cause the client to be disconnected
fields.name: strict_mode

fields.desc: Specify the response information returned to the client. This feature is disabled if is set to "". Applies only to clients using MQTT 5.0.
fields.name: response_information

fields.desc: The keep alive that EMQX requires the client to use. If configured as disabled, it means that the keep alive specified by the client will be used. Requires Server Keep Alive in MQTT 5.0, so it is only applicable to clients using MQTT 5.0 protocol.
fields.name: server_keepalive

fields.desc: The backoff multiplier used by the broker to determine the client keep alive timeout. If EMQX doesn't receive any packet in Keep Alive * Backoff * 2 seconds, EMQX will close the current connection.
fields.name: keepalive_backoff

fields.desc: Maximum number of subscriptions allowed per client.
fields.name: max_subscriptions

fields.desc: Force upgrade of QoS level according to subscription.
fields.name: upgrade_qos

fields.desc: Maximum number of QoS 1 and QoS 2 messages that are allowed to be delivered simultaneously before completing the acknowledgment.
fields.name: max_inflight

fields.desc: Retry interval for QoS 1/2 message delivering.
fields.name: retry_interval

fields.desc: For each publisher session, the maximum number of outstanding QoS 2 messages pending on the client to send PUBREL. After reaching this limit, new QoS 2 PUBLISH requests will be rejected with `147(0x93)` until either PUBREL is received or timed out.
fields.name: max_awaiting_rel

fields.desc: For client to broker QoS 2 message, the time limit for the broker to wait before the `PUBREL` message is received. The wait is aborted after timed out, meaning the packet ID is freed for new `PUBLISH` requests. Receiving a stale `PUBREL` causes a warning level log. Note, the message is delivered to subscribers before entering the wait for PUBREL.
fields.name: await_rel_timeout

fields.desc: Specifies how long the session will expire after the connection is disconnected, only for non-MQTT 5.0 connections.
fields.name: session_expiry_interval

fields.desc: Maximum queue length. Enqueued messages when persistent client disconnected, or inflight window is full.
fields.name: max_mqueue_len

fields.desc: Topic priorities. Priority number [1-255] There's no priority table by default, hence all messages are treated equal. **NOTE**: Comma and equal signs are not allowed for priority topic names. **NOTE**: Messages for topics not in the priority table are treated as either highest or lowest priority depending on the configured value for mqtt.mqueue_default_priority. **Examples**: To configure "topic/1" > "topic/2": mqueue_priorities: {"topic/1": 10, "topic/2": 8}
fields.name: mqueue_priorities

fields.desc: Default topic priority, which will be used by topics not in Topic Priorities (mqueue_priorities).
fields.name: mqueue_default_priority

fields.desc: Specifies whether to store QoS 0 messages in the message queue while the connection is down but the session remains.
fields.name: mqueue_store_qos0

fields.desc: Whether to user Client ID as Username. This setting takes effect later than Use Peer Certificate as Username (peer_cert_as_username) and Use peer certificate as Client ID (peer_cert_as_clientid).
fields.name: use_username_as_clientid

fields.desc: Use the CN, DN field in the peer certificate or the entire certificate content as Username. Only works for the TLS connection. Supported configurations are the following: - cn: Take the CN field of the certificate as Username - dn: Take the DN field of the certificate as Username - crt: Take the content of the DER or PEM certificate as Username - pem: Convert DER certificate content to PEM format as Username - md5: Take the MD5 value of the content of the DER or PEM certificate as Username
fields.name: peer_cert_as_username

fields.desc: Use the CN, DN field in the peer certificate or the entire certificate content as Client ID. Only works for the TLS connection. Supported configurations are the following: - cn: Take the CN field of the certificate as Client ID - dn: Take the DN field of the certificate as Client ID - crt: Take the content of the DER or PEM certificate as Client ID - pem: Convert DER certificate content to PEM format as Client ID - md5: Take the MD5 value of the content of the DER or PEM certificate as Client ID
fields.name: peer_cert_as_clientid

desc:
Overload protection mechanism monitors the load of the system and temporarily
disables some features (such as accepting new connections) when the load is high.

fields.desc: React on system overload or not.
fields.name: enable

fields.desc: When at high load, some unimportant tasks could be delayed for execution, here set the duration in milliseconds precision.
fields.name: backoff_delay

fields.desc: When at high load, skip forceful GC.
fields.name: backoff_gc

fields.desc: When at high load, skip process hibernation.
fields.name: backoff_hibernation

fields.desc: When at high load, close new incoming connections.
fields.name: backoff_new_conn

desc:
Enable/disable statistic data collection.
Statistic data such as message receive/send count/rate etc. It provides insights of system performance and helps to diagnose issues. You can find statistic data from the dashboard, or from the '/stats' API.

fields.desc: Enable/disable statistic data collection.
fields.name: enable

desc: Settings for bcrypt password hashing algorithm.

fields.desc: BCRYPT password hashing.
fields.name: name

desc: Settings for bcrypt password hashing algorithm (for DB backends with write capability).

fields.desc: BCRYPT password hashing.
fields.name: name

fields.desc: Salt rounds for BCRYPT password generation.
fields.name: salt_rounds

desc: Settings for other password hashing algorithms.

fields.desc: Simple password hashing algorithm.
fields.name: name

fields.desc: Salt position for PLAIN, MD5, SHA, SHA256 and SHA512 algorithms.
fields.name: salt_position

desc: Settings for PBKDF2 password hashing algorithm.

fields.desc: PBKDF2 password hashing.
fields.name: name

fields.desc: Specifies mac_fun for PBKDF2 hashing algorithm.
fields.name: mac_fun

fields.desc: Iteration count for PBKDF2 hashing algorithm.
fields.name: iterations

fields.desc: Derived length for PBKDF2 hashing algorithm. If not specified, calculated automatically based on `mac_fun`.
fields.name: dk_length

desc: PSK stands for 'Pre-Shared Keys'. This config to enable TLS-PSK authentication. Important! Make sure the SSL listener with only tlsv1.2 enabled, and also PSK cipher suites configured, such as RSA-PSK-AES256-GCM-SHA384. See listener SSL options config for more details. The IDs and secrets can be provided from a file which is configurable by the init_file field.

fields.desc: Whether to enable TLS PSK support
fields.name: enable

fields.desc: If init_file is specified, EMQX will import PSKs from the file into the built-in database at startup for use by the runtime. The file has to be structured line-by-line, each line must be in the format of PSKIdentity:SharedSecret. For example: mydevice1:c2VjcmV0
fields.name: init_file

fields.desc: The separator between PSKIdentity and SharedSecret in the PSK file
fields.name: separator

fields.desc: The size of each chunk used to import to the built-in database from PSK file
fields.name: chunk_size

desc: After the device logs in successfully, the subscription is automatically completed for the device through the pre-defined subscription representation. Supports the use of placeholders.

fields.desc: After the device logs in successfully, the subscription is automatically completed for the device through the pre-defined subscription representation. Supports the use of placeholders.
fields.name: topics

desc:
Topic name, placeholders are supported. For example: client/${clientid}/username/${username}/host/${host}/port/${port}
Required field, and cannot be empty string

fields.desc:
Topic name, placeholders are supported. For example: client/${clientid}/username/${username}/host/${host}/port/${port}
Required field, and cannot be empty string
fields.name: topic

fields.desc:
Default value 0. Quality of service.
At most once (0)
At least once (1)
Exactly once (2)
fields.name: qos

fields.desc:
Default value 0. This option is used to specify whether the server forwards the retained message to the client when establishing a subscription.
Retain Handling is equal to 0, as long as the client successfully subscribes, the server will send the retained message.
Retain Handling is equal to 1, if the client successfully subscribes and this subscription does not exist previously, the server sends the retained message. After all, sometimes the client re-initiate the subscription just to change the QoS, but it does not mean that it wants to receive the reserved messages again.
Retain Handling is equal to 2, even if the client successfully subscribes, the server does not send the retained message.
fields.name: rh

fields.desc: Default value 0. This option is used to specify whether the server retains the RETAIN mark when forwarding messages to the client, and this option does not affect the RETAIN mark in the retained message. Therefore, when the option Retain As Publish is set to 0, the client will directly distinguish whether this is a normal forwarded message or a retained message according to the RETAIN mark in the message, instead of judging whether this message is the first received after subscribing(the forwarded message may be sent before the retained message, which depends on the specific implementation of different brokers).
fields.name: rap

fields.desc:
Default value 0.
MQTT v3.1.1： if you subscribe to the topic published by yourself, you will receive all messages that you published.
MQTT v5: if you set this option as 1 when subscribing, the server will not forward the message you published to you.
fields.name: nl

desc: The config for MQTT Bridges.

fields.desc: Enable or disable this bridge
fields.name: enable

fields.desc: Resource options.
fields.name: resource_opts

fields.desc:
The mode of the MQTT Bridge.
- cluster_shareload: create an MQTT connection on each node in the emqx cluster.
In 'cluster_shareload' mode, the incoming load from the remote broker is shared by using shared subscription.
Note that the 'clientid' is suffixed by the node name, this is to avoid clientid conflicts between different nodes. And we can only use shared subscription topic filters for remote.topic of ingress connections.
fields.name: mode

fields.desc: The host and port of the remote MQTT broker
fields.name: server

fields.desc:
Reconnect interval. Delay for the MQTT bridge to retry establishing the connection in case of transportation failure. Time interval is a string that contains a number followed by time unit:
- `ms` for milliseconds, - `s` for seconds, - `m` for minutes, - `h` for hours;
or combination of whereof: `1h5m0s`
fields.name: reconnect_interval

fields.desc: The MQTT protocol version
fields.name: proto_ver

fields.desc:
If enable bridge mode.
NOTE: This setting is only for MQTT protocol version older than 5.0, and the remote MQTT
broker MUST support this feature.
fields.name: bridge_mode

fields.desc: The username of the MQTT protocol
fields.name: username

fields.desc: The password of the MQTT protocol
fields.name: password

fields.desc: The clean-start or the clean-session of the MQTT protocol
fields.name: clean_start

fields.desc:
MQTT Keepalive. Time interval is a string that contains a number followed by time unit:
- `ms` for milliseconds, - `s` for seconds, - `m` for minutes, - `h` for hours;
or combination of whereof: `1h5m0s`
fields.name: keepalive

fields.desc:
Message retry interval. Delay for the MQTT bridge to retry sending the QoS1/QoS2 messages in case of ACK not received. Time interval is a string that contains a number followed by time unit:
- `ms` for milliseconds, - `s` for seconds, - `m` for minutes, - `h` for hours;
or combination of whereof: `1h5m0s`
fields.name: retry_interval

fields.desc: Max inflight (sent, but un-acked) messages of the MQTT protocol
fields.name: max_inflight

fields.desc: SSL connection settings.
fields.name: ssl

fields.desc:
The ingress config defines how this bridge receive messages from the remote MQTT broker, and then send them to the local broker.
Template with variables is allowed in 'remote.qos', 'local.topic', 'local.qos', 'local.retain', 'local.payload'.
NOTE: if this bridge is used as the input of a rule, and also 'local.topic' is configured, then messages got from the remote broker will be sent to both the 'local.topic' and the rule.
fields.name: ingress

fields.desc:
The egress config defines how this bridge forwards messages from the local broker to the remote broker.
Template with variables is allowed in 'remote.topic', 'local.qos', 'local.retain', 'local.payload'.
NOTE: if this bridge is used as the action of a rule, and also 'local.topic' is configured, then both the data got from the rule and the MQTT messages that matches 'local.topic' will be forwarded.
fields.name: egress

desc: Creation options.

fields.desc: Resource worker pool size.
fields.name: worker_pool_size

fields.desc: Health check interval, in milliseconds.
fields.name: health_check_interval

fields.desc: The auto restart interval after the resource is disconnected, in milliseconds.
fields.name: auto_restart_interval

fields.desc: Query mode. Optional 'sync/async', default 'sync'.
fields.name: query_mode

fields.desc: Async query inflight window.
fields.name: async_inflight_window

fields.desc: Queue mode enabled.
fields.name: enable_queue

fields.desc: Maximum queue storage.
fields.name: max_queue_bytes

desc: Configuration for an HTTP bridge.

fields.desc: Enable or disable this bridge
fields.name: enable

fields.desc: Resource options.
fields.name: resource_opts

fields.desc: The timeout when connecting to the HTTP server.
fields.name: connect_timeout

fields.desc: Deprecated since 5.0.4.
fields.name: retry_interval

fields.desc: The type of the pool. Can be one of `random`, `hash`.
fields.name: pool_type

fields.desc: The pool size.
fields.name: pool_size

fields.desc: A positive integer. Whether to send HTTP requests continuously, when set to 1, it means that after each HTTP request is sent, you need to wait for the server to return and then continue to send the next request.
fields.name: enable_pipelining

fields.desc: If the request is provided, the caller can send HTTP requests via emqx_resource:query(ResourceId, {send_message, BridgeId, Message})
fields.name: request

fields.desc: SSL connection settings.
fields.name: ssl

fields.desc:
The URL of the HTTP Bridge.
Template with variables is allowed in the path, but variables cannot be used in the scheme, host, or port part.
For example, http://localhost:9901/${topic} is allowed, but http://${host}:9901/message or http://localhost:${port}/message is not allowed.
fields.name: url

fields.desc:
The MQTT topic filter to be forwarded to the HTTP server. All MQTT 'PUBLISH' messages with the topic matching the local_topic will be forwarded.
NOTE: if this bridge is used as the action of a rule (EMQX rule engine), and also local_topic is configured, then both the data got from the rule and the MQTT messages that match local_topic will be forwarded.
fields.name: local_topic

fields.desc:
The method of the HTTP request. All the available methods are: post, put, get, delete.
Template with variables is allowed.
fields.name: method

fields.desc:
The headers of the HTTP request.
Template with variables is allowed.
fields.name: headers

fields.desc:
The body of the HTTP request.
Template with variables is allowed.
fields.name: body

fields.desc: HTTP request max retry times if failed.
fields.name: max_retries

fields.desc: HTTP request timeout.
fields.name: request_timeout

desc: Creation options.

fields.desc: Resource worker pool size.
fields.name: worker_pool_size

fields.desc: Health check interval, in milliseconds.
fields.name: health_check_interval

fields.desc: The auto restart interval after the resource is disconnected, in milliseconds.
fields.name: auto_restart_interval

fields.desc: Query mode. Optional 'sync/async', default 'sync'.
fields.name: query_mode

fields.desc: Async query inflight window.
fields.name: async_inflight_window

fields.desc: Queue mode enabled.
fields.name: enable_queue

fields.desc: Maximum queue storage.
fields.name: max_queue_bytes

fields.desc: HTTP method.
fields.name: method

fields.desc: URL path.
fields.name: path

fields.desc: HTTP request body.
fields.name: body

fields.desc: List of HTTP headers.
fields.name: headers

fields.desc: Max retry times if error on sending request.
fields.name: max_retries

fields.desc: HTTP request timeout.
fields.name: request_timeout

desc:
The egress config defines how this bridge forwards messages from the local broker to the remote broker.
Template with variables is allowed in 'remote.topic', 'local.qos', 'local.retain', 'local.payload'.
NOTE: if this bridge is used as the action of a rule, and also 'local.topic' is configured, then both the data got from the rule and the MQTT messages that matches 'local.topic' will be forwarded.

fields.desc: The configs about receiving messages from local broker.
fields.name: local

fields.desc: The configs about sending message to the remote broker.
fields.name: remote

desc: The configs about receiving messages from local broker.

fields.desc: The local topic to be forwarded to the remote broker
fields.name: topic

desc: The configs about sending message to the remote broker.

fields.desc:
Forward to which topic of the remote broker.
Template with variables is allowed.
fields.name: topic

fields.desc:
The QoS of the MQTT message to be sent.
Template with variables is allowed.
fields.name: qos

fields.desc:
The 'retain' flag of the MQTT message to be sent.
Template with variables is allowed.
fields.name: retain

fields.desc:
The payload of the MQTT message to be sent.
Template with variables is allowed.
fields.name: payload

desc:
The ingress config defines how this bridge receive messages from the remote MQTT broker, and then send them to the local broker.
Template with variables is allowed in 'remote.qos', 'local.topic', 'local.qos', 'local.retain', 'local.payload'.
NOTE: if this bridge is used as the input of a rule, and also 'local.topic' is configured, then messages got from the remote broker will be sent to both the 'local.topic' and the rule.

fields.desc: The configs about subscribing to the remote broker.
fields.name: remote

fields.desc: The configs about sending message to the local broker.
fields.name: local

desc: The configs about sending message to the local broker.

fields.desc:
Send messages to which topic of the local broker.
Template with variables is allowed.
fields.name: topic

fields.desc:
The QoS of the MQTT message to be sent.
Template with variables is allowed.
fields.name: qos

fields.desc:
The 'retain' flag of the MQTT message to be sent.
Template with variables is allowed.
fields.name: retain

fields.desc:
The payload of the MQTT message to be sent.
Template with variables is allowed.
fields.name: payload

desc: The configs about subscribing to the remote broker.

fields.desc: Receive messages from which topic of the remote broker
fields.name: topic

fields.desc: The QoS level to be used when subscribing to the remote broker
fields.name: qos

desc:
Manage EMQX plugins.
Plugins can be pre-built as a part of EMQX package, or installed as a standalone package in a location specified by install_dir config key
The standalone-installed plugins are referred to as 'external' plugins.

fields.desc:
An array of plugins in the desired states.
The plugins are started in the defined order
fields.name: states

fields.desc:
The installation directory for the external plugins. The plugin beam files and configuration files should reside in the subdirectory named as emqx_foo_bar-0.1.0.
NOTE: For security reasons, this directory should **NOT** be writable by anyone except emqx (or any user which runs EMQX).
fields.name: install_dir

fields.desc:
Check interval: check if the status of the plugins in the cluster is consistent,
if the results of 3 consecutive checks are not consistent, then alarm.
fields.name: check_interval

desc: A per-plugin config to describe the desired state of the plugin.

fields.desc:
The {name}-{version} of the plugin.
It should match the plugin application name-version as the for the plugin release package name
For example: my_plugin-0.1.0.
fields.name: name_vsn

fields.desc: Set to 'true' to enable this plugin
fields.name: enable

desc: Settings for reporting metrics to Prometheus

fields.desc: URL of Prometheus server
fields.name: push_gateway_server

fields.desc: Data reporting interval
fields.name: interval

fields.desc: Turn Prometheus data pushing on or off
fields.name: enable

desc: Retainer batching and rate limiting.

fields.desc: Size of the batch when reading messages from storage. 0 means no limit.
fields.name: batch_read_number

fields.desc: The number of retained messages can be delivered per batch.
fields.name: batch_deliver_number

fields.desc:
The rate limiter name for retained messages' delivery.
Limiter helps to avoid delivering too many messages to the client at once, which may cause the client to block or crash, or drop messages due to exceeding the size of the message queue.
The names of the available rate limiters are taken from the existing rate limiters under `limiter.batch`.
If this field is empty, limiter is not used.
fields.name: batch_deliver_limiter

desc: Configuration of the internal database storing retained messages.

fields.desc: Backend type.
fields.name: type

fields.desc: Specifies whether the messages are stored in RAM or persisted on disc.
fields.name: storage_type

fields.desc: Maximum number of retained messages. 0 means no limit.
fields.name: max_retained_messages

fields.desc:
Retainer index specifications: list of arrays of positive ascending integers. Each array specifies an index. Numbers in an index specification are 1-based word positions in topics. Words from specified positions will be used for indexing.
For example, it is good to have [2, 4] index to optimize +/X/+/Y/... topic wildcard subscriptions.
fields.name: index_specs

desc: Configuration related to handling `PUBLISH` packets with a `retain` flag set to 1.

fields.desc: Enable retainer feature
fields.name: enable

fields.desc: Message retention time. 0 means message will never be expired.
fields.name: msg_expiry_interval

fields.desc:
Periodic interval for cleaning up expired messages.
Never clear if the value is 0.
fields.name: msg_clear_interval

fields.desc: Flow control.
fields.name: flow_control

fields.desc: Maximum retained message size.
fields.name: max_payload_size

fields.desc:
When the retained flag of the `PUBLISH` message is set and Payload is empty,
whether to continue to publish the message.
See:
http://docs.oasis-open.org/mqtt/mqtt/v3.1.1/os/mqtt-v3.1.1-os.html#_Toc398718038
fields.name: stop_publish_clear_msg

fields.desc: Settings for the database storing the retained messages.
fields.name: backend

desc: Configuration for `slow_subs` feature.

fields.desc: Enable this feature
fields.name: enable

fields.desc: The latency threshold for statistics
fields.name: threshold

fields.desc: The eviction time of the record, which in the statistics record table
fields.name: expire_interval

fields.desc: The maximum number of records in the slow subscription statistics record table
fields.name: top_k_num

fields.desc: The method to calculate the latency
fields.name: stats_type

desc: StatsD metrics collection and push configuration.

fields.desc: Enable or disable StatsD metrics collection and push service.
fields.name: enable

fields.desc: StatsD server address.
fields.name: server

fields.desc: The sampling interval for metrics.
fields.name: sample_time_interval

fields.desc: The push interval for metrics.
fields.name: flush_time_interval

fields.desc: The tags for metrics.
fields.name: tags
